When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

You didn't know what to think. It was like the world had just turned upside down in an instant. After all of these years, all of the tests and reports, they had finally found something wrong with the drug. But you couldn't help but feel like there was more to it. Why had it taken so long for side effects to show up? And why were they affecting both people who had taken the drug nearly 50 years ago and those who had taken it less than 10 years ago. At the same time? It didn't make sense to you. 

You were still trying to figure it out when you got the call. An old friend of yours - well, weren't they all old now? - called you up and asked you to meet with her. "Don't tell anyone" she said. And you didn't.

You met her at an old restaurant, one stilled owned by another of the Lost Generations. "I need to tell you something." she said. "It's probably going to be hard to hear." She took a deep breath and looked at you, the wrinkles on her face deep with concern. "These side effects aren't side effects of the drug. They are 'side effects' of government policy."

"What!" 

"Shhh" she said. "You must remain calm. We're can't take any risks right now." 

"What are you talking about?" you tried to remain calm, but judging by her face it was not a good performance. 

"The side effects are the result of policy. Think about it, if everyone lives forever the planet can't sustain us all for long. So when the population reaches a certain point, they hold a lottery." She covered her mouth after she said it, as if there was a possibility one of the other patrons would hear.

Oh god, you suddenly understood. It was population control, and anyone who wasn't going to die naturally was a possible target. You suddenly thought about what a crime it was to have the government decide who lives and who dies.

"So, what do we do?" you asked. 

"Well, we're still trying to figure that out. But I have to warn you, you're not going to like what the most likely plan is." 

"I'll do whatever it takes." you said without hesitation.

And we do have a plan. To be honest I lied just now, we know what has to be done. We don't need you, I just wanted to...warn you."

"What is the plan?" 

She looked at you. We are going to destroy the ability to create the drug, all current supplies, and all information related to the drug. It will no longer be available. Soon, and from now on, all humanity will live normal life spans, just like you and I will. Except for those who have already taken the drug."

"What about them?" you weren't sure you could go along with the plan.

She looked somber. "They will die eventually too, rather through accident, suicide, or just neglect. Unfortunately they will have to see many of their younger relatives and friends die. But it is necessary to avoid this dystopian future for all."

You had to admit it made sense. You hated it. But... your children and grandchildren didn't have the "side effects" yet; if this meant they could make their own choices in the future, it was worth it.

You went home and kept silent. You told no one of your conversation.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

You didn't know what to think. It was like the world had just turned upside down in an instant. After all of these years, all of the tests and reports, they had finally found something wrong with the drug. But you couldn't help but feel like there was more to it. Why had it taken so long for side effects to show up? And why were they affecting both people who had taken the drug nearly 50 years ago and those who had taken it less than 10 years ago. At the same time? It didn't make sense to you. 

You were still trying to figure it out when you got the call. An old friend of yours - well, weren't they all old now? - called you up and asked you to meet with her. "Don't tell anyone" she said. And you didn't.

You met her at an old restaurant, one stilled owned by another of the Lost Generations. "I need to tell you something." she said. "It's probably going to be hard to hear." She took a deep breath and looked at you, the wrinkles on her face deep with concern. "These side effects aren't side effects of the drug. They are 'side effects' of government policy."

"What!" 

"Shhh" she said. "You must remain calm. We're can't take any risks right now." 

"What are you talking about?" you tried to remain calm, but judging by her face it was not a good performance. 

"The side effects are the result of policy. Think about it, if everyone lives forever the planet can't sustain us all for long. So when the population reaches a certain point, they hold a lottery." She covered her mouth after she said it, as if there was a possibility one of the other patrons would hear.

Oh god, you suddenly understood. It was population control, and anyone who wasn't going to die naturally was a possible target. You suddenly thought about what a crime it was to have the government decide who lives and who dies.

"So, what do we do?" you asked. 

"Well, we're still trying to figure that out. But I have to warn you, you're not going to like what the most likely plan is."
